author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Family of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her Cells
description: Ms. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission.
content: Henrietta Lacks, a Black mother of five, was dying of cervical cancer in 1951, when doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore took a sample of her cells without her knowledge or consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Joe Rennison
title: Fitch Downgrades U.S. Credit Rating
description: The ratings agency, which lowered the U.S. long-term rating from its top mark, said debt-limit standoffs had eroded confidence in the nation’s fiscal management.
content: The long-term credit rating of the United States was downgraded on Tuesday by the Fitch Ratings agency, which said the nation’s high and growing debt burden and penchant for brinkmanship over America’s authority to borrow money had eroded confidence in its fiscal management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Mike Ives
title: 11 Women Pooled Money for a $3 Lottery Ticket. They Won $1.2 Million.
description: The winners, who are sanitation co-workers in India, each make just a few dollars a day. The jackpot will help them pay off crippling debts.
content: In June, 11 women who work together as sanitation laborers in India pooled their money to buy the equivalent of a $3 lottery ticket because they could not afford the cost individually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Friendly on the Senate Floor, Combatants on the Campaign Trail
description: Senator Steve Daines of Montana, the Republican campaign chief, is taking aim at his home-state colleague Senator Jon Tester, a Democrat in one of 2024’s biggest races. It’s a bit awkward.
content: As the Senate wound down for the summer last week, Senator Steve Daines, Republican of Montana, issued a celebratory news release upon winning approval of a water-rights agreement that had been years in the making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Rogé Karma interviews Martin Wolf
description: The Aug. 1, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Rogé Karma, with Martin Wolf. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Here’s How Indictments Work in the U.S. Legal system.
description: Unlike a criminal trial, where a jury has to reach a unanimous verdict, a grand jury can issue an indictment with a simple majority. Grand jurors hear only from prosecutors and the witnesses they present.
content: An indictment, whether it is handed up in federal or state court, is a formal accusation — not a conviction — and it is among the first moves a prosecutor can make to bring a case to trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Covid Test Company That Got Into the Migrant Business
description: DocGo, which was awarded a $432 million contract by New York City, moved migrants upstate. Some complained about how they were treated.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at how a company that conducted Covid tests during the pandemic came to move hundreds of asylum seekers out of New York City — and what has happened since the migrants arrived in upstate communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Job Turnover Eased in June as the Labor Market Cooled
description: Openings were little changed, but hiring and quitting both declined.
content: Job turnover decreased in June, the Labor Department reported on Tuesday, suggesting that the American labor market continues to slow down from its meteoric ascent after the pandemic lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas and Chang Che
title: Chinese Zoo Denies, in Voice of a Bear, That Sun Bear Is a Person in a Suit
description: “Some people think I look too human when I stand up,” the Hangzhou Zoo’s statement said, after a video prompted internet conspiracy theories. “I am a Malayan sun bear!”
content: Sun, moon, grizzly, black, spectacled, sloth: Bears all over the world can stand, shuffle, totter and walk on two legs, though they usually prefer four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Dyer
title: I Gave Up and Went on a Trip With Several Thousand of My Closest Friends
description: What the resurgence of the cruise industry says about Americans’ desperate need to have fun right now.
content: I’ve hiked the Himalayas, scaled dunes in Namibia, gotten lost on Japan’s back roads in a blizzard. I enjoy travel with an element of chaos and unpredictability because that’s where the excitement lies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Construction to Break German Dependence on Russian Gas Hits a Snag: Wartime Bombs
description: The choreography of finding and clearing unexploded, decades-old munitions has become routine on Germany’s northern coast.
content: In the wake of the war in Ukraine, the port at Wilhelmshaven has emerged as a critical hub for German efforts to break the country’s dependence on Russian energy. It is there, on the North Sea coast, that officials would like to build a giant new terminal to import liquefied natural gas from other sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brontez Purnell
title: I’ve Listened to This Breakup Song a Million Times
description: Why does it feel so good to cry this hard?
content: I’m mobbing through Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the back of a cab, listening to Lady Wray’s “Piece of Me” for the 12th time in a row, and I’m crying — very, very hard — and no, it’s not ugly crying. In fact, I’m pretty sure I look beautiful right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Pee-wee Herman Was Exuberant. Paul Reubens Was Almost Serene.
description: Speaking with the actor was an entirely different experience than watching him play his career-defining character.
content: Pee-wee Herman was noisy. He was boisterous. He had a voice that would shoot up several decibels without warning, whether he was inviting his TV viewers to play a game of connect the dots or interrogating his friends about the whereabouts of his missing bicycle. The mysterious nature of his character — was he supposed to be a man, a child or a man pretending to be a child? — seemed to excuse his exuberant energy and excessive volumes, and he, in turn, gave that same permission to his audience. Like he told us on “Pee-wee’s Playhouse,” his kids’ show that wasn’t really just for kids, “You all know what to do when anyone says the secret word, right?” That’s right: “Scream real loud!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 10 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in August
description: We’ve rounded up the best of what’s leaving this month, which includes a lot of favorites, among them two Oscar winners. Catch them while you can.
content: Two recent (and worthy) Oscar winners lead the list of titles exiting Netflix in the United States this month, alongside two horror favorites, two action extravaganzas and one of the most beloved romantic comedies of its time. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How Martin Wolf Understands This Global Economic Moment
description: The economic journalist on the “shifts,” “shocks” and “fragilities” shaping this global economic moment.
content: The world economy has experienced many shocks over the past few years: A pandemic. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Skyrocketing inflation. These are the stories that have dominated headlines — and for good reason.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Scientists Revive Two Roundworms That Were Encased in Siberian Permafrost for 46,000 Years
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 1, 2023.
content: “That’s the interest of science. You end somewhere you didn’t presume.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika L. Sánchez
title: In ‘My Name Is Iris,’ a Mother Learns the Limits of Protectiveness
description: Brando Skyhorse’s novel is the subtly dystopian story of a Mexican American woman who realizes that America has become less welcoming to people like her.
content: In Brando Skyhorse’s second novel, a conservative Mexican American woman in an unnamed border state rebuilds her life after divorce, in an America that has become an increasingly dangerous white supremacist society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: California’s Largest Wildfire of the Year Sweeps Across the Mojave
description: The York fire, in the southeastern part of the state, has consumed more than 77,000 acres of the Mojave National Preserve and crossed into Nevada, officials said.
content: California’s largest wildfire this year has swept across thousands of acres in the Mojave Desert since the weekend, and has been so powerful that it has produced spinning columns of fire, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘Now Is Our Time to Assemble’: The Week 6 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: Nathaniel T. writes about his love of Marvel movies — and how we, the audience, should support the writers and actors who are striking.
content: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the sixth of our 10-week challenge, we received 1,006 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Nathaniel T., as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Ivan Penn
title: Solar Supply Chain Grows More Opaque Amid Human Rights Concerns
description: The global industry is cutting some ties to China, but its exposure to forced labor remains high and companies are less transparent, a new report found.
content: Global supply chains for solar panels have begun shifting away from a heavy reliance on China, in part because of a recent ban on products from Xinjiang, a region where the U.S. government and United Nations accuse the Chinese government of committing human rights violations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Tom Cruise Roll a Fiat 500 in ‘Mission: Impossible’
description: The director Christopher McQuarrie discusses a chase scene involving the star and Hayley Atwell in ‘Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning Part One’
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: An International Force May Be Headed to Troubled Haiti, Again
description: Kenya has offered to lead a police force to help restore order to Haiti, where gangs that control vast parts of the country’s capital have fomented violence.
content: After nearly a year of calls from the prime minister of Haiti for armed  intervention from abroad, the troubled country may soon get such a deployment from an African nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Jose Llana (a.k.a. Ferdinand Marcos) Makes a Home in the Hamptons
description: When he’s not performing in “Here Lies Love,” a musical about the Philippines’s infamous first couple, this Broadway star finds refuge outside the city.
content: It’s a few days after the Broadway opening of “Here Lies Love,” the David Byrne/Fatboy Slim poperetta that charts the rise and fall of the Philippines’s infamous first couple, Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos. And here sits Jose Llana — he plays Ferdinand — in the kitchen of the Hamptons, N.Y., weekend house he shares with his husband, Erik Rose, a real estate executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Biden 43%, Trump 43%
description: Looking more closely at the registered voters who don’t support Biden or Trump.
content: The first Times poll of the 2024 election cycle shows a dead heat between President Biden and Donald Trump. If those two men are the presidential nominees next year, 43 percent of registered voters say they will support Biden, and 43 percent say they will back Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Orders Nationwide Shutdown Because of ‘Unprecedented’ Heat
description: The government announced a two-day public holiday, ordering all government agencies, banks and schools to close amid soaring temperatures that threatened public health and strained the power grid.
content: Iran on Tuesday announced a two-day public holiday in response to “unprecedented” heat, ordering all government agencies, banks and schools to shut down, an unusual move prompted by soaring temperatures that threatened public health and strained the country’s power grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Bloom
title: Richard E. Grant Fights Grief With ‘A Pocketful of Happiness’
description: The Oscar-nominated actor’s new memoir is at once a Hollywood air kiss and a moving tribute to a happy marriage that ended too soon.
content: Richard E. Grant is a wonderful actor and, it seems, a rather wonderful (goofy, talented, loving) man. His new memoir, written in diary form, is about his terrific 38-year marriage-of-opposites to Joan Washington (he the eternal adolescent, star-struck optimist and gifted actor, she a sharp-tongued, no-nonsense and equally gifted dialect coach) and her painful death from cancer. (It is she who, while dying, instructs him to seek a “pocketful of happiness” every day after she is gone.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: New Voices Dominate Booker Prize Nominations
description: Four of the 13 books that will compete for the prestigious literary award are debuts, in a longlist that the judges said was “defined by its freshness.”
content: A graceful novel about a squash prodigy battling grief on court, a dystopia that reimagines Ireland as a totalitarian state and a coming-of-age tale about a neurodiverse teenager are among 13 titles longlisted for this year’s Booker Prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Bulb Becomes a Flashpoint as the Sun Sets on Incandescent Lights
description: A ban on most kinds of traditional bulbs renews a cultural squabble between regulatory efforts to curb energy consumption and the very American impulse to do whatever one wants in one’s domicile.
content: The switchboard at Lightbulbs.com, a (pretty self-explanatory) e-commerce website, lit up with panicked callers on Tuesday, who all wanted to know if the news was true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Hard-Drug Decriminalization Disaster
description: How soon is too soon to call a progressive and libertarian policy obsession a public policy fiasco? In the case of Oregon’s Drug Addiction Treatment and Recovery Act, better known as Measure 110, the moment can’t come soon enough.
content: How soon is too soon to call a progressive and libertarian policy obsession a public policy fiasco? In the case of Oregon’s Drug Addiction Treatment and Recovery Act, better known as Measure 110, the moment can’t come soon enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Crunch Muscles, for Short
description: Kathryn Ladner branches out.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: At the Roosevelt Library, an Unflinching Look at Race
description: A new exhibition at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library explores the president’s “mixed” record on civil rights — and the charged debate over racism in the New Deal.
content: In October 1935, President Franklin D. Roosevelt had his administration send letters to thousands of clergy across the country, asking if the New Deal was helping their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A Soup and Salad That Beat the Heat
description: Capped off with a raspberry-nectarine icebox cake, this menu from David Tanis is cool enough for the hottest of days.
content: This August menu is essentially designed for beating the heat on seriously sweltering summer days, when ice-cold everything seems appropriate. We’re on the right track, I think, with a chilled soup, followed by a room-temperature vegetable salad and a dessert straight from the refrigerator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Books That Explain California
description: The nation’s most populous state is a vast and complex place. Fiction and nonfiction suggested by readers can help make sense of it.
content: Although I grew up in California, my assigned reading in school didn’t offer much of a Golden State-specific education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Solar Power’s China Problem
description: Many of the industry’s key materials are made with forced labor.
content: It’s never been cheaper or easier to produce electricity from the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: DeSantis Suggests Trump Can’t Get a Fair Trial in D.C. ‘Swamp’
description: It was an unusual attack leveled at the District of Columbia and its residents.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida raced to respond to news that former President Donald J. Trump had been indicted a third time not by opining one way or the other on the new federal charges, but by leveling an unusual attack at residents of the District of Columbia, where the case is being prosecuted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Reilly
title: It’s Not Too Late to Buy a Great One-Piece Swimsuit
description: It’s sale season for swimwear, a great time to upgrade your basic old go-to.
content: August might seem a little late to shop for swimsuits, but it’s also the time of year when many of us may finally be on vacation — and, hopefully, in or near a body of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Horowitz
title: Consider This Before You Judge Commander (or Any Other Dog)
description: We are holding dogs to standards they cannot possibly understand.
content: Any dog can bite. It is the special misfortune of dogs living in the most famous house in the United States to have their bites widely publicized, amplified and scrutinized. And so when Commander, the German shepherd who lives with President and Jill Biden, began biting, his behavior made headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Swan
title: After Paying Lawyers, Trump’s PAC Is Nearly Broke
description: The scramble to cover legal bills for former President Donald J. Trump and his associates has prompted what appears to be the largest refund in federal campaign finance history.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s political action committee, which began last year with $105 million, now has less than $4 million left in its account after paying tens of millions of dollars in legal fees for Mr. Trump and his associates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: A Poet Captures the Terror of Life in an Authoritarian State
description: A memoir by Tahir Hamut Izgil, a Uyghur intellectual who escaped China, explores the corrosive effect of repression and surveillance on his community.
content: Tahir Hamut Izgil watched as parks emptied of people, naan bakeries boarded up their windows and, one after another, his friends were taken away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP Reports Sharply Lower Earnings as Oil Prices Slide
description: The energy company offset a slide in profit by raising its dividend by 10 percent.
content: BP reported on Tuesday a sharp slide in profits in the second quarter, with earnings falling about 70 percent from the record-breaking totals of a year earlier. Adjusted profits were $2.6 billion, compared with $8.5 billion in the same period a year earlier, BP said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rowan Moore Gerety
title: Saving Lives at the Grand Canyon, One Salty Snack at a Time
description: In a summer of deadly heat for hikers in the Southwest, rangers at Grand Canyon National Park use a pioneering approach of aggressive messaging and outreach to prevent disaster on the trails.
content: Watching weary day hikers start the long uphill hike from Phantom Ranch, a ranger station at the bottom of the Grand Canyon, Jeff Schwartz has learned to look for telltale warning signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
title: Under Hindu Nationalist Leaders, Sectarian Violence Flares in India
description: A gunman who killed Muslim train passengers and a Hindu march that turned riotous underscore how the partisan stances of India’s top Hindu leaders have given license to chaotic elements in the country.
content: In the early hours of Monday, on a train bound for Mumbai, India’s commercial capital, a police officer took up his service rifle, fatally shot his superior and then killed three unarmed passengers. All three of the passengers were Muslim men, according to Indian news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Arrogance of Samuel Alito
description: In theory, there is no branch in the American constitutional system that exists above or beyond the reach of the others.
content: In theory, there is no branch in the American constitutional system that exists above or beyond the reach of the others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: For American Soccer Fans, a Late Night Was a Tense One
description: Or was it an early morning? However they looked at it, neither beer nor Bloody Marys could fully soothe the anxieties of fans hoping the United States would advance.
content: Fans of the Women’s World Cup in the United States on Tuesday had a critical decision to make based on a distinctive 3 a.m. kickoff: Stay up late or wake up early?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Here Are the Charges Trump Faces in the Jan. 6 Case
description: The former president is charged with three conspiracy counts and the corrupt obstruction of an official proceeding.
content: The newly unsealed indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday leveled four criminal counts against him over his efforts to stay in power after the 2020 election: a conspiracy to violate civil rights, a conspiracy to defraud the government, the corrupt obstruction of an official proceeding and a conspiracy to carry out such obstruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Yemen Café, a Brooklyn Standby, Expands to Staten Island
description: A former Gallaghers chef opens a sandwich shop, a wine series pops up at the Noortwyck, and more restaurant news.
content: What does owning restaurants have in common with flying? Both are risky endeavors, and both are Akram Nassir’s careers. He’s a captain for Delta Air Lines and has just opened another Yemen Café. While achieving his dream of becoming a pilot, he went into the restaurant business with his father and uncle. He still flies, weaving his schedule  with his restaurant duties. His father, Muthamma Nassir, was a chef at Windows on the World and opened the original Yemen Café in 1986 with a relative, Yahya Alsubai, on the stretch of Atlantic Avenue bordering Brooklyn Heights, a neighborhood clustered with Middle Eastern restaurants and shops. Akram Nassir says it was the first Yemeni restaurant in New York, if not the United States. In 2011, he opened another in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Now, he and his partner, Mr. Alsubai, have branched out to Staten Island. There, they will again serve a Middle Eastern community, he said. The latest Yemen Café, a spacious room with a traditional fishing boat hanging on one wall, has outdoor seating. As at the other locations, the specialty is lamb more than a dozen ways, notably slow-cooked, succulent falling-off-the-bone cuts like shanks and shoulder. There are also chicken dishes and Middle Eastern appetizers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
title: Trump Meddler in Michigan, Matthew DePerno, Is Charged in Election Breach
description: A key figure in a multistate effort to overturn the 2020 election, Mr. DePerno lost his race for Michigan attorney general in 2022. He later finished second to lead the state’s Republican Party.
content: Matthew DePerno, a key orchestrator of efforts to help former President Donald J. Trump try to overturn the 2020 election in Michigan and an unsuccessful candidate for state attorney general last year, was arraigned on four felony charges on Tuesday, according to documents released by D.J. Hilson, the special prosecutor handling the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Was Indicted Over His Efforts to Overturn the 2020 Election
description: Also, Europeans evacuate from Niger. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Donald Trump, the former president and current front-runner for the Republican nomination, was indicted today in connection with his widespread efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Adam Goldman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Moving at High Velocity, Special Counsel Brings 2nd Indictment Against Trump
description: The special counsel Jack Smith has undertaken two historic investigations with remarkable speed, aggressiveness and apparent indifference to collateral political consequences.
content: Last fall, a largely unknown former prosecutor with a beard and a brisk gait flew unnoticed to Washington from The Hague after being summoned to a secret meeting by Attorney General Merrick B. Garland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Venice Faces an Unwelcome Honor: Joining the Endangered Places List
description: The United Nations’ culture agency is warning of twin perils to the historic city from mass tourism and climate change.
content: To protect its fragile ecosystem and stunning architecture, Venice has taken bold steps. In recent years, it has banned cruise ships from its lagoon and built sea walls to keep out high tides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Review: In ‘Amour,’ Putting a Palme d’Or Winner Onstage
description: An adaptation of Michael Haneke’s 2012 movie at the Salzburg Festival eschews cinematic realism, instead taking a highly stylized approach.
content: “How can I speak of love when I’m dead?” runs a powerful line in “Amour,” a stage adaptation of Michael Haneke’s 2012 film that premiered on Sunday at the Salzburg Festival, in Austria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A School Bus Crosses U.S., Linking Families of Mass Shooting Victims
description: As mass shootings multiply, relatives of the dead find support in “the worst club imaginable.” One child’s parents are on a road trip to connect them.
content: Manuel and Patricia Oliver had already been on the road for more than a week when they pulled their school bus bearing an American flag into a city park in Uvalde, Texas. They were unsure of just how many people would greet them on that sweltering day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Frying Pans and Fiscal Policy
description: Why the 2010s were an economic tragedy
content: Today I want to talk about frying pans. No, I haven’t joined the staff of Wirecutter. I’m talking instead about a suddenly popular new type of economic chart, dubbed “frying pan charts” by Alex Williams of Employ America. Here’s an example, depicting the percentage of Americans in their prime working years actually employed:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: After Investigation and Complaints, Twitter Removes ‘X’ on Headquarters
description: Residents near the company’s location in downtown San Francisco complained of “intense” flashing lights and feared for their safety.
content: Workers on Monday dismantled a giant “X” sign that was only briefly displayed on the roof of Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco after residents complained and the city issued a violation notice for lacking proper permits, according to local officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carroll
title: ‘Family Lore’ Is a Tender Tale of Sisterhood, With a Magical Twist
description: In Elizabeth Acevedo’s new novel, a family grapples with life and grief after their sister, who can predict death, decides to host a wake for herself.
content: Family is very often a fraught business, but make it a group of Dominican women with special gifts that include “an affinity for herbalism” and “an ear for the tenor of truth,” and family becomes a power tribe of ancestral legionnaires. These are the Marte sisters — Matilde, Flor, Pastora and Camila — who live at the center of Elizabeth Acevedo’s prismatic new novel, “Family Lore,” a labyrinthine tale of sisterhood and the chaos of love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Malle
title: Being Underestimated Was Her Secret Weapon
description: In “Flirting With Danger,” Janet Wallach tells the story of Marguerite Harrison, who traded a life of privilege to become America’s first international female spy.
content: Anyone complaining about a canceled Delta flight would do well to channel Marguerite Harrison. The United States’ first international female spy, Harrison crisscrossed the globe by rickshaw, propeller plane, camel, inflated goatskin raft and rail freight car and once brightly described a trans-Siberian voyage, in which she was wedged between sacks of tea and oats on the back of a troika in a blizzard, as “a rare and delightful experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Aung San Suu Kyi’s Prison Sentence Reduced in Myanmar
description: The civilian leader, who was ousted in a coup in 2021, had six years cut from a 33-year prison sentence and five of her 19 convictions overturned, state television said.
content: The military government in Myanmar has reduced the prison sentence for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Southeast Asian nation’s ousted civilian leader, by six years, a military spokesman said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Lynsey Chutel
title: Wednesday Briefing: Coups and Conflict in West Africa
description: Also, some “Barbenheimer” promotion sparks outrage in Japan.
content: Nearly a week after a military takeover in Niger, there’s still uncertainty about who is truly in charge there, and the coup is threatening to set off a regional conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K.’s New Alcohol Taxes Are Aimed at Keeping Pubs Open and Votes Flowing
description: The changes are the biggest shake-up to Britain’s alcohol levies in 140 years, according to a government whose leader was clearly on the campaign trail in announcing them.
content: When Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak, a teetotaler, dropped in on a west London beer festival on Tuesday, he was looking for votes rather than pints while promoting a government policy that he said would ease the financial squeeze on some of Britain’s drinkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper, Alan Blinder and Lauren Hirsch
title: Tiger Woods Joins PGA Tour Board in Concession to Player Demands
description: With the addition of Woods, players will outnumber independent directors, giving them the final say in the tour’s plan to form a partnership with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.
content: Infuriated after being blindsided by the PGA Tour’s pact with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, a band of leading golfers has won a series of concessions from the beleaguered circuit’s commissioner — including the elevation of Tiger Woods to the tour’s board — in a star-driven rebuke of the tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Laser
title: Christian Nationalists Can’t Wait for This School in Oklahoma to Open
description: A religious public charter school would be an affront to taxpayers everywhere.
content: Something deeply un-American is underway in the state of Oklahoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Back From the Edge, U.S. Tries to Focus on What Comes Next
description: A close call against Portugal at the Women’s World Cup gave the United States a chance to consider what might have been, and then move past it.
content: From where she stood, the ball looked to be headed straight into the goal, and Megan Rapinoe cursed loudly in her head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Is Menopause Changing My Hair?
description: Shifting hormones can make hair go haywire. Experts say there are ways to manage it.
content: Q: Since going through menopause, I’ve noticed changes to my scalp and hair texture — my scalp is dry and flaky, and my hair is dry and falling out. What’s going on, and is there anything I can do to address it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Mets Continue to Deal, Sending Justin Verlander Back to Astros
description: Verlander won the World Series and the American League Cy Young Award with Houston last season. His short stint with the Mets yielded six wins for him and two top prospects for the team.
content: When the Mets paired Justin Verlander with Max Scherzer last off-season, it seemed almost too perfect. In Scherzer, they had one right-hander with three Cy Young Awards and a $43.3 million annual salary. In Verlander — who had just won his second World Series title with the Houston Astros — they had another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker
title: Biden Shores Up Democratic Support, but Faces Tight Race Against Trump
description: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that President Biden is on stronger footing than he was a year ago — but he is neck-and-neck in a possible rematch against Donald Trump.
content: President Biden is heading into the 2024 presidential contest on firmer footing than a year ago, with his approval rating inching upward and once-doubtful Democrats falling into line behind his re-election bid, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Aging and Health of Our Leaders
description: Readers write about older politicians. Also: Donald Trump vs. Jack Smith; the photo of a dead Russian soldier; an AIDS program; the freedom to read.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Move Over, Men: Women Were Hunters, Too
description: Anthropologists are finding that women in modern foraging societies have played a major role in catching game.
content: It’s often viewed as a given: Men hunted, women gathered. After all, the anthropological reasoning went, men were naturally more aggressive, whereas the slower pace of gathering was ideal for women, who were mainly focused on caretaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: $30: The Entrance Fee to America’s Museums Keeps Rising
description: Their buildings have expanded and expenses have surged, even as attendance slowed. Art lovers will bear the cost: The Guggenheim is the latest to increase its price of admission to $30 — the new normal.
content: Audience sizes just aren’t what they used to be at the Guggenheim Museum, where membership — once a dependable source of income — has declined by nearly 16 percent since 2019, and attendance in June slumped by 26 percent, from 89,600 to 65,900, over the same time frame. What has increased is the cost of running the institution. A newly unionized work force has bumped up salary expenses, while inflation is driving up the cost of everything from heating to shipping artworks, according to senior museum officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: The Sorcerer of Costumes
description: Many eras coexist inside the studio of the Emmy-winning costume designer Donna Zakowska.
content: Clothes hold a visceral thrill for Donna Zakowska. “There’s a sensuality and a tactile aspect to fashion,” she said. “I’m always thinking about the quality of the garment, the fabric, the way it plays with light and air and movement — about the emotional impact of color.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Glenn Thrush
title: A Craigslist for Guns, With No Background Checks
description: A federal gun law passed last year gave the Biden administration a powerful new tool to increase background checks on “private” firearms sales. Will the administration use it?
content: Another school week had just begun at Central Visual and Performing Arts High School in St. Louis when Orlando Harris, armed with a recently purchased AR-15-style rifle and 600 rounds of ammunition, burst into the building with a declaration: “You are all going to die!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Edward Sexton, Bespoke Tailor of Rock ’n’ Roll, Dies at 80
description: With his partner, Tommy Nutter, he outfitted London celebrities at the tail end of the Swinging Sixties — and beyond — in suits with swagger.
content: Edward Sexton, a master tailor who, with his business partner, Tommy Nutter, upended the staid British institution that was Savile Row with Nutters, a shop with rock ’n’ roll flair and clientele, died on July 23 in London. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Sheila Oliver, New Jersey’s Trailblazing Lieutenant Governor, Has Died
description: Ms. Oliver, 71, was the first Black woman to hold statewide elected office there, after a long tenure in the General Assembly.
content: Sheila Y. Oliver, New Jersey’s lieutenant governor and the first Black woman to hold statewide elected office there, died on Tuesday after being rushed to the hospital the day before. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: How to Talk About Wordle
description: How to play Wordle and a glossary of important terms
content: Thanks to reader Outside Observer for compiling this glossary of common terms people use when talking about Wordle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Biden’s Poll Numbers Get Stronger, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘The Half-God of Rainfall’ Review: Basketball Under the Heavens
description: Borrowing its powers from Greek and Yoruba mythologies, Inua Ellams’s play tells the story of a demigod who becomes an N.B.A. superstar.
content: Turning verse into action is tricky, especially with ideas as lofty as the ones in Inua Ellams’s epic poem “The Half-God of Rainfall,” now appearing in theatrical guise at New York Theater Workshop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Migrants Sleep on the Sidewalk, the Face of a Failing Shelter System
description: People have come from all over the globe to a city that is legally required to give them a place to stay. This week, city officials said they had run out of room.
content: They came from Colombia and Chad, from Burundi, Peru, Venezuela, Madagascar. In New York they had heard there was a haven for immigrants, a place to live and get back on their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: 505-Million-Year-Old Jellyfish Fossils May Be the Oldest Ever Found
description: The specimens are evidence of how little the squishy, tentacled predators have changed over the history of life on Earth.
content: Jellyfish have been floating through Earth’s oceans seemingly forever. But pinning down the exact origin of these squishy sea creatures, which are some of the earliest complex animals, is difficult. They rarely show up in the fossil record because jellyfish are 95 percent water and are prone to rapid decay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Isn’t Funny in Nuclear-Scarred Japan
description: The Japanese subsidiary of Warner Bros. criticized what it called insensitive promotion of “Barbie” by the company’s headquarters.
content: To Americans eager for signs of life in an ailing cinema culture, the simultaneous box office success of the “Barbie” movie and the biopic “Oppenheimer” has been cause for celebration, with filmgoers embracing the jarring juxtaposition of the two very different blockbusters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Besonen and Lanna Apisukh
title: Favorite Drinks of All the Top Stars? He Has Them Memorized.
description: “Joe” Petrsoric, the longtime bartender at Broadway’s go-to saloon, is finally retiring.
content: In 1968, Sardi’s was still enjoying its decades-long heyday, commanding the limelight as Broadway’s foremost hub of show folk, from big shots to wannabes to poignant has-beens. Playwrights, agents, publicists and newspaper columnists vied for strategic tables in the restaurant’s dining room, trading artful glances, gossip, poisoned barbs and air kisses. Elated tourists, always an ingredient of the Sardi’s experience, basked in the presence of Groucho Marx or Liza Minnelli entering to applause, a Sardi’s tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Steve Jobs’s Son Gets Into Venture Capital
description: Reed Jobs, 31, is starting an investment firm to focus on new cancer treatments, continuing a yearslong focus on a disease that hits close to home.
content: Reed Jobs is stepping into the spotlight: The 31-year-old son of Steve Jobs and Laurene Powell Jobs is starting a venture capital firm to invest in new cancer treatments, DealBook is the first to report. It’s an area that hits close to home, since his father, the iconic Apple co-founder, died from complications of pancreatic cancer in 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Atlanta Sheriff Rules Out Special Treatment if Trump Is Indicted There
description: Officials in Georgia are bracing for possible trouble around the Fulton County Courthouse, where indictments related to election interference are expected in mid-August.
content: The sheriff of Fulton County, Ga., said on Tuesday that if former President Donald J. Trump were to be indicted in connection with efforts to overturn the 2020 election in the state, he would not receive special treatment, and would be booked and photographed like any other defendant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Uber Posts 14% Rise in Revenue as Growth Slows
description: The company’s growth decelerated as the rebound from the pandemic normalized and its freight business declined. It also swung to a profit.
content: Uber’s revenue increased 14 percent in its most recent quarter, the company reported on Tuesday, but the growth was its slowest since the coronavirus pandemic began easing last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Is Indicted in His Push to Overturn Election
description: The former president faces three conspiracy charges and a count of attempting to obstruct an official proceeding in his campaign to use the levers of government power to remain in office.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump was indicted on Tuesday in connection with his widespread efforts to overturn the 2020 election following a sprawling federal investigation into his attempts to cling to power after losing the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: David Hallberg’s New Job: Decision Maker
description: The former American Ballet Theater star now leads the Australian Ballet. “When I am faced with difficulties, I lean into them,” he said.
content: It was March 2020, and David Hallberg, who had weathered more than two years of injury and physical rehabilitation, was back in the saddle, rehearsing “Swan Lake” with Natalia Osipova at the Royal Opera House in London. Then the world shut down as the Covid-19 pandemic and lockdowns became a new reality. Hallberg, a resident guest principal at the Royal Ballet and a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, saw his packed schedule of performances collapse like a house of cards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Paul Reubens Was More Than Pee-wee. Here are 8 Great Performances.
description: He played dozens of memorable roles on big and small screens throughout his career. We’ve rounded up what to watch and where to watch it.
content: Paul Reubens, who died on Sunday at age 70, will always be remembered for his beloved alter ego, the perpetually childlike Pee-wee Herman — a character so popular that it was able to carry a stage show, movies and a TV series. But Reubens also made memorable impressions playing a variety of supporting characters of the big and small screens — like Penguin’s father in “Batman Returns” and the turtleneck-wearing fixer Mr. Vargas in “The Blacklist,” just to name a few out of dozens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: A Senator’s New Wife and Her Old Friends Draw Prosecutors’ Attention
description: Unlike her husband, Nadine Menendez has lived a mainly private life. Investigators appear focused on the possibility that she or the senator received undisclosed gifts.
content: In early 2019, Senator Bob Menendez of New Jersey and his new girlfriend, Nadine Arslanian, were riding high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: How You Should Change Your Workout Once You Hit 40
description: Making a few tweaks to your fitness habits — and mind-set — as you hit middle age can set you up for long-term mobility with less pain.
content: Getting older doesn’t have to mean moving less. The key to longstanding fitness, experts say, is envisioning the kind of athlete you want to be 20, 30, even 40 years from now, and training smartly in the present for that future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia Herring
title: The Woman Behind the ‘Hot Girl Summer’ Necklace
description: Taylor Sade is the founder of Vertigo, which sells chokers, pendants and belts made of beads that look as if they were plucked from the beach.
content: By day, Taylor Sade, 24, is a marketing manager. But after work hours, she hand-strings beads and stones on her bed in her Lower East Side apartment, cradled next to her two Himalayan cats. Those creations eventually add up to Vertigo, the buzzy brand behind the accessory draping the necks and waists of many young women this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik and Maggie Haberman
title: More Republicans Say Trump Committed Crimes. But They Still Support Him.
description: The share of Republicans saying the former president has committed “serious federal crimes” has grown modestly, according to a new poll from The New York Times and Siena College.
content: Follow live updates as Trump is indicted over efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Where to Eat After Visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and More Reader Questions
description: An Italian restaurant with a little elbow room? No problem.
content: Hi friends, I hope you all made it through this weekend’s heat wave in good shape. (I ran straight to the beach.) I’m back with another edition of reader questions and, boy, do we have an interesting mix this month. There’s a visitor from the South searching for “decent Thai” — and we can do much better than decent. Another reader wants to know where to enjoy cozy Italian dining, minus the physical closeness to other diners. And finally, someone seeking bistro lunchtime options near the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a gossip session.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Suspect in Gilgo Beach Killings Hears Catalog of Evidence Against Him
description: Suffolk County’s district attorney personally appeared at a brief session for the man accused of murder in three cases and named as the prime suspect in a fourth.
content: The voices of those seated in a Long Island courtroom fell to a whisper on Tuesday as Rex Heuermann, his mouth drawn tight, shuffled in, his hair rumpled and his wrists handcuffed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Gross
title: People Get Scared and Buy a Gun. Here’s What Happens Next.
description: Fear of crime is a self-fulfilling prophecy.
content: Violent crime — homicides, robberies, gun assaults — has begun to fall from pandemic-era levels. But people are scared. According to the Pew Research Center, almost 60 percent of Americans today say that violent crime is a “very big problem.” In New York State, four out of ten residents tell pollsters they’ve “never been this worried about my personal safety.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Let’s Call Her Patty’ Review: Unseen Depths of an Uptown Matriarch
description: Rhea Perlman stars as a quintessential Upper West Sider in Zarina Shea’s snapshot of affluent, self-flagellating motherhood
content: She shops at Zabar’s, does Pilates on Columbus Avenue and resides comfortably in a prewar high rise between West End and Riverside, where she gossips about private lives as though they were front-page news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: These Characters Need Therapists. ‘Cinema Therapy’ Is Here for Them.
description: Two YouTube hosts have built a following by dissecting the psychology of movie characters. Here, they analyze some of this summer’s familiar faces.
content: Is Indiana Jones better at burying his feelings than digging up priceless artifacts? How might Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver’s characters in “Marriage Story” have better navigated divorce and co-parenting? Hey, wait a minute: Does the hero of “The Lego Batman Movie” contain all the building blocks of a narcissist?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: ‘The Nanny’ Comes Home to New York and Gives Studio Heads a Talking-to
description: Fran Drescher, the actress and union leader, leaned into her Queens roots in a City Hall appearance to urge support for the actors’ strike.
content: Inside New York’s vaulted City Council chamber, the actress Fran Drescher was about to address council members about the plight of the thousands of actors on strike whom she represents as the president of their union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marnie Hanel
title: What Happened to Diamond Crystal Kosher Salt?
description: With minimalist branding and a higher price point, the salt brand is now chasing after “the aspiring home chef.”
content: On a recent Friday morning, the cookbook author Molly Baz put the finishing touch on a new recipe for shingled tomato toast with sesame mayo. Reaching into a wooden salt cellar, she grabbed a three-finger pinch of salt and showered her dish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: octogenarian
description: This word has appeared in 57 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word octogenarian has appeared in 57 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 8 in “At 81, Ann-Margret Is Finally Living Her Rock ’n’ Roll Dream” by Jim Farber:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Lee
title: Is It Justice or a Journey Into Hell, or Both?
description: In Kyle Dillon Hertz’s novel, “The Lookback Window,” a victim of child sexual abuse questions what healing looks like when a law gives him the chance to press charges against his assailants.
content: “I didn’t yet have the words for what happened to me,” says Dylan, the narrator of “The Lookback Window,” Kyle Dillon Hertz’s gripping and savagely beautiful debut novel. But he has covered himself with language. There are tattoos all over his body. Only a few can be made out clearly: “PARADISE” on his navel, “NO DEATH” across his collarbone, knucklebangers proclaiming “FOREVER.” People always want to know what they mean, but the meaning isn’t the point. The tattoos “felt like armor,” Dylan says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: Planning to Visit Barcelona or Dubrovnik? It’s Going to Cost You.
description: Driven by the climate crisis, the post-pandemic surge in visitors and a growing interest in making tourism work for local communities, European cities are finding new ways to tax visitors.
content: When Hester Van Buren, a deputy mayor of Amsterdam, recently proposed a 1 percent increase to the city’s tourist accommodation tax — which is already among the highest in Europe — her City Council colleagues responded with a single criticism: They wanted the increase to be even bigger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Can the Race Really Be That Close? Yes, Biden and Trump Are Tied.
description: A Times/Siena poll suggests a slight Biden edge among voters who don’t like either candidate.
content: After Democrats fared well against MAGA candidates in the midterms last year, it might have been reasonable to think that President Biden would have a clear advantage in a rematch against Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko, Alina Lobzina and Victoria Kim
title: A Drone Strike in Moscow and a Message: Russia Is Not Safe
description: The same building housing Russian government offices was hit twice within 48 hours.
content: A building in central Moscow housing government ministries was struck by a drone Tuesday for the second time in 48 hours, as Ukrainian officials make it increasingly clear that they are not going to allow the war to be limited to their own soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imogen West-Knights
title: 3 Young Irish Writers and Their ‘Difficult Second Books’
description: Exciting debuts from Naoise Dolan, Megan Nolan and Nicole Flattery suggested a new direction in Irish literature. Now, where will they take it?
content: In recent years, Irish novelists, and particularly Irish women novelists, have published some of the most compelling English-language literary fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Dionne Searcey
title: Deadly Protests in Senegal as Opposition Party Is Dissolved and Leader Detained
description: Ousmane Sonko, a fiery figure with a loyal youth following, was charged with fomenting insurrection, and his party dissolved.
content: Senegal’s government has dissolved the country’s main opposition party and detained its leader on charges of fomenting insurrection, setting off a new round of protests in which two people were killed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: The details of Ukraine’s drone strikes.
content: A Times investigation found evidence that at least three different Ukrainian-made drone models had been used in attacks inside Russia, including Moscow, indicating a Ukrainian role in strikes that Kyiv has denied carrying out or declined to claim responsibility for. Ukraine is racing to scale up its drone fleet, and to attack more frequently in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: It’s Official: Stores Can No Longer Sell Most Incandescent Lights
description: New efficiency rules, more than a decade in the making, have taken effect, relegating Edison’s glowing orbs to the history books.
content: It’s the end of an era. In America, the incandescent light is no more (with a few exceptions).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: A Deadly Summer for Hikers in the Southwest
description: At least seven heat-related deaths are suspected in state and national parks during a record-breaking heat wave.
content: For hikers in the American Southwest, this searing hot summer has been an exceptionally dangerous one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Georgy Birger
title: Putin’s Crackdown Leaves Transgender Russians Bracing for Worse
description: A new law underscores how Vladimir V. Putin is increasingly using the war in Ukraine as justification for greater restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. life, portraying it as a consequence of deviant Western values.
content: Jan Dvorkin had raised and nurtured his adopted son in Moscow for seven years until, one day in May, the Russian authorities notified him they were revoking custody. A woman Mr. Dvorkin knew had filed an official complaint, saying that because he was transgender and gay, he was an unfit parent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorothy Wickenden
title: The Sea Captain Who Ran From Abraham Lincoln
description: In “Shipwrecked,” the historian Jonathan W. White tells the story of an outlaw mariner who worked for the Confederacy and against the Klan.
content: Who was Appleton Oaksmith? One contemporary described him as a “good seaman, & a bold & daring officer.” His enemies, President Abraham Lincoln among them, judged him a scoundrel and a traitor. Oaksmith, writing six years after the Civil War, wasn’t sure what to think: “I look upon myself sometimes with a sort of doubt as to my own identity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus Kondkar, Calvin Duncan, Alexander Stockton and Jesse Wegman
title: They Know What They Did. They’d Like You to Know Who They’ve Become.
description: These men have spent their entire adult lives in prison. How much punishment is enough?
content: Listening to the men in the short Opinion Video above is like encountering visitors from another planet. They are serving life sentences at Angola prison, in rural Louisiana, with little to no hope for release. Many are elderly; they have not seen the outside world, or their families, for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: A Stairway to Nowhere Sells for $32,000 in London
description: An entrepreneur saw what others didn’t and now owns the unused set of stairs, which are attached to the back of a suburban building.
content: Even by the standards of London’s white-hot real estate market, it was a property with seemingly limited appeal: an unused stairwell, attached to the back of a suburban building, next to a parking garage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Biden Cancels Space Command Move to Alabama Amid Tuberville Feud
description: The Pentagon said the decision was because of military readiness, but it comes as the Republican senator from Alabama has held up military promotions to protest an abortion access policy.
content: The Pentagon announced on Monday that President Biden had canceled an order by former President Donald J. Trump to move the United States Space Command headquarters to Alabama, prompting an outcry from Republicans who accused him of acting out of political spite amid a fierce partisan standoff over the Pentagon’s abortion access policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: NASA’s Voyager 2 Is Out of Contact but Not Lost in Space
description: The aging spacecraft’s antenna was misdirected by a glitch, although officials say the distant probe appears to be functioning as intended.
content: Voyager 2, the aging explorer of our solar system, appears to be alive and well, NASA officials said on Tuesday. But they may not be able to communicate with the spacecraft for at least the next two months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 Songs About August
description: The dog days are over. Here are some tunes to celebrate.
content: Happy August. It’s the month of out-of-office auto replies, finally breaking heat waves, and — if the songs about August are to believed, anyway — waning summer romances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Shannon Lin, Lynsea Garrison, Michael Simon Johnson, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The Secret History of Gun Rights
description: How the N.R.A. became a lobbying juggernaut.
content: How did the National Rifle Association, America’s most influential gun-rights group, amass its power?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Felt Like a Particle of Light’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: In the 11th summer of my life, I befriended a local boy on Ocracoke Island. Tall, soft-spoken, with a mop of red-blonde hair that sometimes hid his blue eyes, he was one of the few people who showed me sweet-tempered kindness while my family dissolved into alcoholism. I remember holding hands, the whooping calls of tree frogs and humid, inky-black evenings at the ocean’s edge — bioluminescent sand sparking as we kicked it up. On the cusp of adolescence, I felt like a particle of light, suspended in a love as platonic and gentle as the moon those summer nights. — Marie Koltchak
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
title: A Run of Strong Data Buoys Biden on the Economy
description: Voters continue to rate the president poorly on economic issues, but there are signs the national mood is beginning to improve.
content: President Biden and his aides are basking in what is arguably the best run of economic data to date in his presidency. Inflation is cooling, business investment is rising, job growth is powering on and surveys suggest rising economic optimism among consumers and voters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 1, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 1, 2023.
content: A picture caption with an article on Friday about the 70th anniversary of the armistice that halted the Korean War misstated the length of that conflict. It lasted about three years and one month, not less than three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Mexico’s ‘Monster’ Trucks Show Cartels Taking Drug War to Next Level
description: Taking the monster truck concept to deadly new realms, cartels are modifying pickups with gun turrets, steel armoring and battering rams.
content: In the United States, some truck owners delight in modifying their rigs with oversized wheels, heavy-duty suspension kits and soot-spewing exhaust systems, turning them into the monster trucks that stalk organized events like demolition derbies and mud bogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Elegantly Dressed Peruvian Cuisine Makes Landfall in TriBeCa
description: At Artesano, the chef Rodrigo Fernandini is making refined versions of ceviches, tiraditos and other dishes.
content: A melody drifted across the dining room like a smoke ring: “Tall and tan and young and lovely. …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Divvy Wants to Make Rent-to-Own Deals Easy. Many Customers Find Them Hard.
description: The start-up’s innovative business model has helped some renters save for a down payment on their home, but others have walked away frustrated by the company.
content: The three-bedroom house in suburban Atlanta on a quiet cul-de-sac seemed exactly what Jeneyha Wheatley-Frett and her husband, Shawn Frett, were looking for when they moved in about 15 months ago with their three children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Demick
title: A Uyghur’s Lament for a Persecuted People
description: In his memoir, “Waiting to Be Arrested at Night,” the poet Tahir Hamut Izgil evokes the fear and danger of daily life for a Chinese ethnic minority that has been the target of a brutal crackdown.
content: The Uyghur poet Tahir Hamut Izgil’s new memoir, “Waiting to Be Arrested at Night,” is an outlier among books about human rights. There are no scenes of torture, no violence and few sweeping proclamations about genocide. Izgil writes with calculated restraint. As his title suggests, the terror is in the anticipation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh, Elian Peltier and Dionne Searcey
title: Europeans Evacuate Niger Amid Risks of Wider Conflict
description: Tensions were rising in the West African nation over demands by African and Western countries to reinstate a president ousted in a military takeover.
content: More than 250 Europeans were evacuated from the West African nation of Niger on Tuesday on a plane sent by France, nearly a week after a coup threatened to set off a regional conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis’s Super PAC Burned Through $34 Million as He Slid in Polls
description: The group behind Ron DeSantis had more money than those backing his rivals, including Donald J. Trump. But big spending has not helped his standing so far.
content: The super PAC supporting the presidential campaign of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida spent nearly $34 million in recent months, pouring money into voter outreach, advertising, polling, consultants and other expenses as his standing in the polls steadily slipped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Hikari Hida and Amy Chang Chien
title: Another Powerful Cyclone Threatens Japan and China
description: Typhoon Khanun was barreling through the Pacific days after an earlier tropical cyclone, Doksuri, brought death and destruction to the region.
content: A powerful tropical cyclone was approaching islands in southern Japan on Tuesday, days after another one slammed into mainland China and the Philippines and left dozens of people dead or injured across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The indictment says Trump had six co-conspirators in his efforts to retain power.
description: While their identities could not be determined, their descriptions match up with a number of people who were central to the investigation of Jan. 6.
content: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump mentions — but does not identify by name — six co-conspirators who prosecutors say worked with him in seeking to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cree LeFavour
title: Edan Lepucki’s Third Novel Makes the ‘Cult of Motherhood’ Literal
description: In “Time’s Mouth,” a time traveler forms a cult for pregnant women in the woods of Northern California.
content: In Edan Lepucki’s third novel, “Time’s Mouth,” a runaway named Sharon finds herself pregnant, alone and in semi-permanent possession of a sprawling Victorian in the woods outside Ben Lomond, Calif. By now she has changed her name to Ursa. She turns the house into a refuge for pregnant women who come to be called “the mamas.” She bans all males other than sons. She also forms a cult around her ability to go back in time, a practice referred to as “transporting” or “tunneling.” Magical stones and a mint tea ritual are involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At Bayreuth, the Work on Wagner’s Operas Is Never Done
description: At the festival that Wagner founded, a new “Parsifal” looks different depending on how you see it, and a workshop model refreshes revivals.
content: After the enormous risk of its beginning, the Bayreuth Festival in Germany was for a long time a place where the stagings of Richard Wagner’s operas were encased in amber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Danube Ports, a Lifeline for Ukraine, Come Under Russian Threat
description: Since the collapse of the Black Sea grain deal two weeks ago, small ports on the Danube River are the only shipping outlet for millions of tons of grain.
content: When Russia blockaded Ukrainian ports on the Black Sea after its full-scale invasion last year, grain that could feed millions worldwide piled up in silos. Crude iron that supplied some thirty percent of American steel makers stopped arriving. Roughly half the world’s supply of the neon used in lasers to make chips was taken off the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Summer Done Simply: Sheet-Pan Chicken With Basil and Spicy Corn
description: Marinate your chicken thighs in pickled jalapeño brine, then toss the peppers with fresh summer corn and lime for a dinner that’s spicy, sweet, salty and sour.
content: It’s cruel that the best time of year to bake is also when you’re least likely to want to turn on the oven, and yet every summer I heat up the kitchen baking cherry pie and blueberry crisp. Desserts made with peak fruit are irresistible, and I mean that literally: I can’t resist them. I know we’re here to talk dinner, but if you have some spare time in low-key August, then you might want to know about these: peach cobbler, blueberry pie and lemon-blackberry shortcakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump’s Case Has Broad Implications for American Democracy
description: The third indictment of the former president is the first to get to the heart of the matter: Can a sitting leader of the country spread lies to hold onto power even after voters reject him?
content: In the long annals of the republic, the White House has seen its share of perfidy and scandal, presidents who cheated on their wives and cheated the taxpayers, who abused their power and abused the public trust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Muhammad
title: Is There a Right Way to Talk About Black Culture?
description: In the essay collection “Dark Days,” Roger Reeves tries to sidestep mainstream arguments to engage deeply with the way people actually live and think.
content: Consider the Black Square. In the summer of 2020, not long after George Floyd’s murder in Minneapolis and a few months into pandemic lockdown, people who felt galvanized to act took to Instagram or Facebook, replacing their profile pictures with a plain black box to signal their support for Black victims of racism. The Square epitomized that moment’s sometimes-futile rhetoric around race and Blackness. Its content-less status — political speech as the absence of any actual speech — drove home how hemmed in we were by platforms that commodified our expressions into repetitive, thoughtless forms. We swapped out ideas and conversation for memes that illuminated nothing. Everybody was talking; few of us were saying anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gemma Sieff
title: Talking About Love in the Afternoon, Morning, Evening and Night
description: Reading Claude Anet’s provocative 1920 novel “Ariane: A Russian Girl,” the reader may yearn for a little less conversation.
content: It would be nice if we had put to bed, so to speak, witless and reductive double standards about female promiscuity. Have you heard the one that goes, “A key that opens many locks is a master key, yet a lock that is opened by many keys” is … unprintably bad? Me neither — until I saw it on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Alyce McFadden
title: Pro-Haley Group Plans $13 Million Ad Push in Iowa and New Hampshire
description: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor and United Nations ambassador, has been struggling to gain traction in a crowded Republican field dominated by Donald Trump.
content: A super PAC supporting Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign said on Tuesday that it had reserved more than $13 million in television and digital ads in Iowa and New Hampshire starting in August. The outlay is the first major advertising push in support of Ms. Haley since she became the first Republican to challenge former President Donald J. Trump this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: A 12-Foot Statue Without a Pedestal, Metaphoric or Otherwise
description: The London-based artist Thomas J Price’s sculptures are larger than life, challenging norms about who gets to be memorialized in bronze.
content: The London-based artist Thomas J Price’s sculptures are larger than life, challenging norms about who gets to be memorialized in bronze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
title: The Trump Jan. 6 Indictment, Annotated
description: The federal indictment unveiled on Tuesday charges former President Donald J. Trump with four crimes related to his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, culminating in the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021.
content: The federal indictment unveiled on Tuesday charges former President Donald J. Trump with four crimes related to his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, culminating in the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mahogany L. Browne
title: A Hip-Hop Love Story in Lyrics
description: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of hip-hop, we asked the poet and author Mahogany L. Browne to write a love letter to the genre, composed entirely of lyrics both beloved and obscure.
content: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of hip-hop, we asked the poet and author Mahogany L. Browne to write a love letter to the genre, composed entirely of lyrics both beloved and obscure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cross-Tabs: July 2023 Times/Siena Poll of the 2024 Race and National Issues
description: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump are tied in a 2024 rematch among all registered voters, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from July 23 to 27, 2023.
content: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump are tied in a 2024 rematch among all registered voters, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from July 23 to 27, 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Topline Results: July 2023 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters
description: Responses from a survey of 1,329 registered voters nationwide, including an oversample of 818 registered Republican voters, conducted July 23-27, 2023
content: Responses from a survey of 1,329 registered voters nationwide, including an oversample of 818 registered Republican voters, conducted July 23-27, 2023

author: By Molly Cook Escobar, Andrew Fischer and Eleanor Lutz
title: Who Has Made It to the First Republican Debate So Far?
description: At least seven candidates appear to have made the cut so far for the first debate in August. Donald J. Trump has indicated he may not attend.
content: At least seven candidates appear to have made the cut so far for the first debate in August. Donald J. Trump has indicated he may not attend.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Old Saybrook, N.Y.
description: This Middlesex County community was once a place “where middle-class people built cottages.” Now cash buyers are winning bidding wars here.
content: This Middlesex County community was once a place “where middle-class people built cottages.” Now cash buyers are winning bidding wars here.

title: At Home With Jose Llana
description: When he’s not performing in “Here Lies Love,” this Broadway star finds refuge in the Hamptons.
content: When he’s not performing in “Here Lies Love,” this Broadway star finds refuge in the Hamptons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus Kondkar, Calvin Duncan and Alexander Stockton
title: They Know What They Did. They’d Like You to Know Who They’ve Become.
description: These men have spent their entire adult life in prison. How much punishment is enough?
content: These men have spent their entire adult life in prison. How much punishment is enough?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: ‘Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning Part One' | Anatomy of a Scene
description: Christopher McQuarrie narrates a scene from the film, featuring Tom Cruise and Hayley Atwell.
content: Christopher McQuarrie narrates a scene from the film, featuring Tom Cruise and Hayley Atwell.

author: By The New York Times
title: Trump Indicted in 2020 Election Investigation
description: Jack Smith, the special counsel overseeing the investigation, filed charges against former President Donald J. Trump in connection with his efforts to remain in power after losing the 2020 election.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel overseeing the investigation, filed charges against former President Donald J. Trump in connection with his efforts to remain in power after losing the 2020 election.

author: By Axel Boada and Ang Li
title: ‘We’re Left Outside’: Nearly 200 Migrants Wait as N.Y.C. Struggles to Provide Shelter
description: A day after Mayor Eric Adams said New York City had run out of shelter space, migrants tell us how they are spending their days eating and sleeping outside the Roosevelt Hotel, hoping to get into the city’s intake center.
content: A day after Mayor Eric Adams said New York City had run out of shelter space, migrants tell us how they are spending their days eating and sleeping outside the Roosevelt Hotel, hoping to get into the city’s intake center.
source.name: The New York Times
